Charles Sanders Peirce and William James

plausible_answers.text: the basic insights of empirical (experience-based) and rational (concept-based) thinking

qas.question: What was the tangent of pragmatism that Peirce didn't like?

context: <a0_0>In <b8_0>the late 19th and early 20th century<b8_0/><a0_0/> several forms of pragmatic philosophy arose. The ideas of pragmatism, in its various forms, developed mainly from discussions between <a1_0>Charles Sanders Peirce and William James<a1_0/> when both men were at <a2_0>Harvard<a2_0/> <a3_0>in the <b5_0><b7_0>1870s<b7_0/><b5_0/><a3_0/>. James popularized the term "<b6_0>pragmatism<b6_0/>", giving Peirce full credit for its patrimony, but Peirce later demurred from the tangents that the movement was taking, and redubbed what he regarded as the original idea with the name of "<a4_0>pragmaticism<a4_0/>". Along with its pragmatic theory of truth, this perspective integrates <b9_0>the basic insights of empirical (experience-based) and rational (concept-based) thinking<b9_0/>.
